node.contents: One of my main AsyncTasks seems to be crashing occasionally (the progress bar freezes and the process stops) and I wondered if I was doing something wrong in my code.

astNode.text: One of my main AsyncTasks seems to be crashing occasionally (the progress bar freezes and the process stops) and I wondered if I was doing something wrong in my code.

node.contents: It looks like it may happen when my Galaxy S2 starts to run low on battery - it seems to coincide with some errors regarding the brightness controls. Although whether these are the cause of the error or result from the error is something I haven't been able to determine. Also, since the battery always seems to be running low this may not even be related!

astNode.text: It looks like it may happen when my Galaxy S2 starts to run low on battery - it seems to coincide with some errors regarding the brightness controls. Although whether these are the cause of the error or result from the error is something I haven't been able to determine. Also, since the battery always seems to be running low this may not even be related!

node.contents: Is there anything that I'm doing in this AsyncTask that is wrong? I'm actually only using the AsyncTask to display one of three progress bars (the computer players) before executing the actual computer's turn with a handler.

astNode.text: Is there anything that I'm doing in this AsyncTask that is wrong? I'm actually only using the AsyncTask to display one of three progress bars (the computer players) before executing the actual computer's turn with a handler.

node.contents: Also this has never been reported on the Android market. If it is caused by the InterruptedException should I also print the stack trace so that I get the user error when it occurs for my end users?

astNode.text: Also this has never been reported on the Android market. If it is caused by the InterruptedException should I also print the stack trace so that I get the user error when it occurs for my end users?

comments.text: // Execution of the task with a random integer value

node.contents: I've finally got a report from the market about this issue. You can see that the AsyncTasks are all waiting for something. Could this be caused by setting the duration of the progress bar as Daniel and Vito have stated or is there something else wrong?

astNode.text: I've finally got a report from the market about this issue. You can see that the AsyncTasks are all waiting for something. Could this be caused by setting the duration of the progress bar as Daniel and Vito have stated or is there something else wrong?

node.contents: Thanks Vito. My AsyncTask is a private class within the main Activity so I don't need to send the activity separately but this looks great.

astNode.text: Thanks Vito. My AsyncTask is a private class within the main Activity so I don't need to send the activity separately but this looks great.

node.contents: The method doInBackground of AsyncTask is executed in a separated Thread. onPreExecute and onPostExecute methods are executed in UI Thread. You can manipulate UI elements only if you are on the UI Thread. If you want to manipulate UI from AsyncTask.doInBackground, you have to use runOnUiThread method:

astNode.text: The method doInBackground of AsyncTask is executed in a separated Thread. onPreExecute and onPostExecute methods are executed in UI Thread. You can manipulate UI elements only if you are on the UI Thread. If you want to manipulate UI from AsyncTask.doInBackground, you have to use runOnUiThread method:

node.contents: The runOnUiThread() is a method of the Activity class. You can use it as I writed only if you declare the AsyncTask class inside your Activity. If it is declared out from Activity class, you can pass a reference to the Activity in the constructor of the AsyncTask, for using it to call runOnUiThread()

astNode.text: The runOnUiThread() is a method of the Activity class. You can use it as I writed only if you declare the AsyncTask class inside your Activity. If it is declared out from Activity class, you can pass a reference to the Activity in the constructor of the AsyncTask, for using it to call runOnUiThread()

node.contents: Is your question answered then? Can you mark it as answered? Thank you :-).

astNode.text: Is your question answered then? Can you mark it as answered? Thank you :-).

node.contents: Thanks Daniel. I knew I couldn't update the UI from the background thread but because it never raised an error and didn't seem to be doing anything bad I didn't even consider that updating the length of the progress bar could impact things this way.

astNode.text: Thanks Daniel. I knew I couldn't update the UI from the background thread but because it never raised an error and didn't seem to be doing anything bad I didn't even consider that updating the length of the progress bar could impact things this way.

node.contents: Updating the UI from other thread does not always raise an exception (I think it almost never raises an exception in Android, but for example in .NET you would instantly get a runtime exception). The thread can freeze and stop if you access UI compontents from it.

astNode.text: Updating the UI from other thread does not always raise an exception (I think it almost never raises an exception in Android, but for example in .NET you would instantly get a runtime exception). The thread can freeze and stop if you access UI compontents from it.

node.contents: You can't manipulate the UI from other threads. And I see that you are calling mProgressBar.setMax(delayTime - 1); inside the doInBackground() method, which is executed in a background thread. This will cause problems. You have to move this code inside onPreExecute() or other method.

astNode.text: You can't manipulate the UI from other threads. And I see that you are calling mProgressBar.setMax(delayTime - 1); inside the doInBackground() method, which is executed in a background thread. This will cause problems. You have to move this code inside onPreExecute() or other method.

node.contents: I think the problem here (apart from trying to manipulate UI from non-main thread, which is of course wrong) lays in Samsung S2 device: please look at this.

astNode.text: I think the problem here (apart from trying to manipulate UI from non-main thread, which is of course wrong) lays in Samsung S2 device: please look at this.
